title: Liberation Through Amplification
description:
This project reimagines the electric guitar as a tool for spatial and sonic exploration. By utilizing both a hexaphonic and MIDI pickup, I can isolate and manipulate each string as an independent voice, creating intricate textures of sound. The work is presented in the Audio Lab at 370 Jay Street and employs a 50-speaker Dolby Atmos system to create an immersive environment where sound dynamically moves through space.

You will experience a live sound installation and concert that blurs the boundaries between performance and environment. Each note,  signal, and sonic element is precisely placed, enveloping the listener in a constantly shifting aural landscape.

This work challenges conventional notions of music and sound art by combining experimental guitar techniques with advanced spatial audio technologies. It explores amplification as a means of increasing volume and as a medium for reimagining space, storytelling, and human connection in a hyper-technological context.

title: Suspend Hangers
keywords: Infrastructure/Architecture, Interaction Design, Web Design, Accessibility

title: seen/unseen
description: This project explores the transformation of self in the digital age, particularly focusing on the tension between our physical presence and our digital footprints. By combining static print photography with moving digital video projections, I aim to juxtapose the tangible and the intangible, emphasizing how we, as physical beings, are constantly being transformed into data in a digitized world.

title: Synapse
description:
Synapse is designed to represent the cycle of setting intentions, making choices, and seeing those intentions materialize. In the creative field, every project begins with a spark—an idea, a feeling, or an intention. But it’s the actions we take in response to that initial spark that transform it into a real, shareable creation. The project thus symbolizes the artist's journey, highlighting the connection between touch (representing effort or engagement) and the visible movement of the flower (representing progress or realization of intentions).

The mirror setup surrounding the glass dome amplifies this metaphor, allowing the viewer to see multiple angles of the flower and reflect upon the various dimensions of their own creative aspirations. It invites introspection: as users reach out to touch the sensor, they initiate a tangible transformation that mirrors the way intentionality and creativity evolve.

title: The Projected: Original Character Development
description:
We often find ourselves drawn to a character, as if captivated by a mirror that responds. Perhaps Freud and Lacan's psychoanalytic theories can explain this action somehow—that a character isn’t just a character, but a reflection of an “ideal self” we can never approach. In this reflection, in the mirror image of the character, we find the echoes of countless unseen thoughts intertwining and watching one another. Within the character’s appearance, we see fragments of divided selves—pieces of pasts, or parts of futures we have yet reached.

I imagine a space, a dialogue: an interaction between audience and a figure inside of the mirror that is more than observation—it’s an experiment in discovery. Lacan believed that the human’s self-recognition begins in infancy, shaped by the reflections in mirrors we see. Through this imagined character, we return to that beginning, peeking into the strong connection between “I” and “Other.” This character waits beyond the mirror. Its form is shifting and elusive because it is always our inner reflection—a recombination of our self and our fantasies.

In the process of constructing and interacting with this fictional figure, I continuously reconsider and reshape ourselves. Through its existence, we see the essence of idealized forms of the self we pursue, and in this lies a different kind of truth. Our emotions flow between the mirrors and ourselves, and those attachments and fascinations we believe to be preferences—could they, in fact, be a kind of illusion, a self-absorbed reverie？
keywords: Participatory Research and Design, Interaction Design

title: Hà Nội (Hanoi)
description: Hà Nội, a city close to my heart where I was born and raised, is the core inspiration for this work. As an international student abroad, I created it as a tribute to my hometown, blending nostalgia with its modern transformation. The painting juxtaposes symbols of Hà Nội’s past and present: bright LED ads and skyscrapers contrast with the familiar scenes of old Hà Nội—newspaper stands, flower vendors, and communist propaganda. An accompanying audio piece captures the vibrant soundscape of Hà Nội’s streets, immersing viewers in its atmosphere. This work explores cultural memory and identity, bridging personal nostalgia with the universal experience of place and belonging.
keywords: Interaction Design, Audio Archives, Cultural Competence

title: Lanterns of Life
description:
This installation, Lanterns of Life, invites viewers into an immersive exploration of the Five Elements—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth—through the mediums of light and shadow. Inspired by the rich symbolism of traditional Chinese philosophy, this work reimagines these elemental forces as living, breathing energies. Each lantern embodies a distinct essence, creating a shifting landscape that responds to the viewer’s movement, allowing for an intimate, interactive experience.

Drawn to the interplay between ancient wisdom and modern interactive art, I aim to bring the elemental connections of nature into a contemporary context. This installation not only celebrates the timelessness of natural cycles but also speaks to our enduring curiosity about the unseen forces that shape our world. By merging traditional cultural themes with sensory technology, Lanterns of Life engages viewers in a moment of reflection on the harmony and balance within the natural and human worlds.

title: Ascent
description: Ascent is a financial literacy application for young Black adults. The racial wealth gap has been prevalent in the United States since the 19th century and has roots in the historical use of restrictive policies, household income, education, financial investment and inheritance. As a result, today’s black middle-class are predominantly first-generation investors making financial decisions without many social or familial ties with experience in economic activities. Financial literacy is essential as knowledge on the subject is key to making informed decisions that result in accumulated wealth. However, developing financial literacy is at times hindered by its omission from school curriculums, the overwhelming manner in which it is taught, and for some minorities, the absence of successful models. My aim is to offer a thorough and interactive method to learning financial literacy and practicing it in your own life. I employ the strategies of gamification in education and offer users modules that will help initiate action in their financial journey.
keywords: Community/Owned Design, Interaction Design, Web Design, Cultural Competence

title: Synesthesia Studio
description: Synesthesia Studio emerged from my fascination with the intersection of color, sound, and emotion. Inspired by the phenomenon of synesthesia, this project invites viewers to explore an immersive experience where the color of their clothing translates into a unique blend of visuals and audio. Inside a darkened and personal space, each participant’s clothing color is detected, triggering a video and sound aligned with that color. By merging art and technology, Synesthesia Studio creates a personal, sensory-driven interaction, allowing participants to experience the moods and atmospheres that colors can evoke. This work transforms everyday choices into a meaningful and reflective sensory experience.

title: Trace
description:
As we go through life, we leave countless traces behind. 

The paths we walk each day, the places we visit, and every choice we make accumulate as unique marks of our journey. 

This project aims to visually capture these footprints we leave throughout our lives.

title: Back On Tracktion
description: Back On Tracktion is a racing game concept made in Unreal Engine 5. It features UX and graphic design, 3D models, animation, custom shaders, and code created by the artist, Noa Kirschbaum. Always remember to have fun, regardless of if you win or lose!

title: Drifting Through
description: A music video that explores the concepts of time and space while being an homage to breakcore. Will blend elements of 2D and 3D animation!

title: Phenomenology of Placelessness
description: My work delves into the alienation and dysphoria of a world where technology and hyper-modernity fragment identity and erode empathy. At its center, a figure lies in a coffin, suffering, while a helmet visualizes his brain activity. Viewers are invited to engage with this experience by interacting with a gamified simulation of his pain, highlighting the disconnect we feel toward individuals who, too fragmented for neat categorization, risk being overlooked or misunderstood by society’s systems. Inspired by Edward Relph’s concept of placelessness and Heidegger’s critique of dwelling, this piece parallels Italo Calvino’s The Nonexistent Knight, where a character’s hollow existence within an impersonal structure becomes a metaphor for a humanity that is present yet invisible.

title: Sustainable Micro Housing
description: My senior project focuses on sustainable housing solutions that help alleviate the housing crisis affecting many urban areas. Having grown up in NYC, I understand how high rents and paycheck-to-paycheck living make homeownership nearly impossible for average families. For this project, I’ll explore the concept of floating houses as a viable option for NYC, demonstrating proposed locations and selecting materials to create housing that is both sustainable and affordable.
keywords: Community/Owned Design, Infrastructure/Architecture, Participatory Research and Design

title: Bunny Mag
description: Bunny Mag is a visually driven magazine and art book hybrid. It explores themes of friendship, girlhood, and life as a 20 something living in New York City. Through playful yet carefully curated visuals and pieces provided by friends and admired creatives, Bunny Mag celebrates zine culture and all things handmade.
keywords: Community/Owned Design, Social Media/Podcasting, Photography, Web Design

title: My Music and Emotions throughout College.
Poco
description:
Poco is a mobile app experience that invites users to a “blind date” with Western Classical Music each day—a curated piece designed to spark curiosity and bring the genre into daily life. The app provides personalized recommendations paired with brief contextual notes, allowing listeners to connect with each piece on an emotional level.

As I was growing up, I developed a lasting love for Western Classical Music through early piano lessons and later, the double bass. Over time, I noticed how difficult it can be for younger generations without a music background to connect with classical pieces, often feeling it’s too formal or inaccessible. Poco is my answer to making Classical Music approachable and enjoyable in a way that doesn’t feel forced or overwhelmed, offering listeners an easy gateway into the rich beauty of it.

title: Deck.ai
description: Deck.ai provides marketers with an AI-driven platform that automates the creation of professional, brand-consistent presentation decks from brief prompts, increasing efficiency and creativity in the campaign planning process.

title: how to (not) be a writer
description:
Throughout the past four years, I've always struggled with choosing between what I feel obligated to do and what I actually want to do. It's how I landed up at IDM actually--computer science was not for me and I was uninterested in trying to pretend that it was.

how to (not) be a writer is an exploration of identity, loss, discovery, and everything else that indecisive college students go through. Stylized as a playbill, little bits and pieces of the past four years of my life offer snapshots into moments that I believe have shaped me into the person I am today.

title: 360 Stellar Odyssey
description: My senior project ‘Stellar Odyssey’ which is a 360 VR Animation Music Video set in the depths of space, is a culmination of years of exploration, creativity, and a lifelong fascination with dreams and sci-fi.  Viewers navigate a vast space setting with 360-degree animation, interacting via mouse to explore surreal landscapes. This project merges my visual direction, music, and animation to create a multi-sensory journey that feels both otherworldly and deeply personal. Featuring COMING TO YOU SEOUL from DPR ARCHIVE, the music’s dreamy, shifting melody perfectly complements the visuals, guiding viewers through an experience that showcases VR’s potential as a powerful storytelling tool. This project reflects my passion for blending art and technology, inviting viewers to actively explore and connect with new worlds.
keywords: Community/Owned Design, Interaction Design, Inter-action Design
